Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I stood in the living room, my stepmother’s voice echoing as she handed me the ceremonial candle. “It’s your turn to lead this year, to show you’re truly part of our family.” Her eyes were hopeful, and my step-siblings watched, waiting for me to accept the honor. My phone buzzed in my pocket—messages from my activist group. The protest downtown had taken a turn; police were blocking exits, and people needed guidance to stay safe. I was supposed to be there, helping coordinate our response, making sure no one got hurt. My stepmother’s expectation weighed on me: to honor the family, to prove I belonged. But my friends at the protest needed me, too. I felt my chest tighten, torn between the warmth of family acceptance and the urgent call to action for justice. Both sides demanded all of me, right now, and I didn’t know how to choose.
